How to keep yourself motivated

There are days in which you feel invicible. It’s great when you’re excited about a goal, a new topic, or when you have an inspiring chat with a friend and the impossible seems achievable. During these days we’re confident in our ideas, we can influence people and get them excited, and we can carry a special emotional power that lights up our time and makes us feel alive and positive about our future.

There are other days in which laziness and routine just take over. We don’t feel like working and we’re uninterested in putting effort in even the simplest tasks. There are times in which we lack passion and drive.

It’s important to understand this is normal. For a long time I felt guilty for feeling tired or lazy or not so interested in what I considered life goals of mine. And most of the time I just was too tired or overwhelmed.
Our mood depends on how tired we are, on our diet, on our expectations, and another million things. So please do expect to have up and down periods.

Whilst I do not want to push against my natural mood swings, I’ve discovered a bunch of tips that help me overcome these moments and get back to a great excited, positive and active mood:

Hang out with inspiring people

Favour funny, exciting, interesting people over negative ones! Do ask them to hang out with you, invite them for dinner, host them if you can. Sharing positive attitude is vital to keep you motivated. Avoid people who tend to complain too much, or have no desire to improve and live life at its fullest.

Read inspiring books

There are books who can inspire and improve our willing to chase our dreams. Keep them and reread them whenever necessary!
I tend to read inspiring books for 10/15 minutes after breakfast. That really set the right pace for the day and make me focus on the important things.

Rest, Rest, Rest

There are people who achieve success at 20, others at 50. If you’re tired and are not
